name: Darul Qasim

judge_issues.message: The rationale mentions strong financial stability and fundraising efficiency, but doesn't explicitly connect these to the overall score of 53. It could be clearer about how these strengths are balanced against the weaknesses to arrive at the final score.
The impact rationale mentions a significant 29.3 months of working capital but doesn't explicitly state that this is considered excessive, which negatively impacts the score.
ZAKAT-ELIGIBLE claimed but no explicit zakat evidence found on website

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Darul Qasim earns 53/100 due to moderate impact and moderate alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

dimension_explanations.alignment: The charity demonstrates medium donor fit by offering zakat-eligible giving options and addressing the urgent need for global Islamic education [3][7]. Its curriculum, including the Shaykh al-Hind program, aligns with traditional epistemological frameworks intended for the Muslim community [4][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: Darul Qasim focuses on capacity building through long-term religious education, allocating a program expense ratio of 51.9% toward its academic initiatives [1][6]. While the organization maintains a significant 29.3 months of working capital, the direct cost per beneficiary is not publicly detailed in available filings [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Darul Qasim is an Islamic institution dedicated to preserving and imparting traditional knowledge derived from the prophethood of Muhammad through rigorous academic programs.
strengths: High fundraising efficiency with only $0.02 spent per $1 raised
Robust liquidity with 29.3 months of working capital available
Clear zakat eligibility and distribution policy for eligible students
baseline_narrative.summary: Based in Glendale Heights, Illinois, Darul Qasim facilitates religious education and Arabic language studies through its Shaykh al-Hind and Intermediate Islamic Studies programs [1][4]. The organization reported a total revenue of $3,290,091 and maintains a zakat-eligible status to support its educational mission [1][3].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization shows strong financial stability and fundraising efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by a mid-range program expense ratio and limited external data transparency.

areas_for_improvement.context: The <cite id="7">51.9% program expense ratio</cite> is below the <cite id="8">78.4% peer median</cite>, suggesting a high portion of funds are held in reserve or directed to administrative costs.

case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="7">relatively low program expense ratio</cite> and excessive liquidity, which may suggest that donations are not being deployed as rapidly as they are received.

confidence.notes: Financial data is robust, but transparency and outcome reporting are limited.

credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should seek a Candid transparency seal and publish annual impact reports.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value the preservation of traditional Islamic epistemology and want to invest in long-term religious institutional infrastructure in America.

Value high financial stability and low fundraising overhead
Prefer supporting established institutions with a 20+ year track record
giving_considerations: Gifts contribute to a highly liquid organization with large reserves
Impact is measured through intellectual capacity building rather than humanitarian metrics
Financial transparency is basic compared to major international NGOs
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking immediate humanitarian relief or those who prioritize charities with high program-to-reserve ratios.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a <cite id="18">verified theory of change</cite> but a lack of publicly available data on student outcomes or post-graduation impact.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization uses a <cite id="2">traditional curriculum</cite> to produce scholars capable of navigating modern challenges through the lens of <cite id="4">classical Islamic epistemology</cite>.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that educational programs effectively prepare students for religious leadership roles.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the charity has high reserves, its <cite id="4">23.4% growth rate</cite> suggests it is scaling its academic offerings.

strengths.detail: The organization operates with minimal overhead in its development efforts, spending just <cite id="10">$0.02 per $1 raised</cite>.
Darul Qasim maintains <cite id="6">29.3 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, ensuring long-term institutional stability.
The institution has achieved a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of 23.4%</cite>, indicating increasing donor trust and scale.

strengths_deep_dive: Darul Qasim's primary strength lies in its institutional stability and specialized curriculum. The organization has successfully transitioned into an established entity with <cite id="13">total assets exceeding $10 million</cite>. Its governance is supported by an <cite id="14">independent board of 8 members</cite>, ensuring oversight of its <cite id="15">$3.29 million annual budget</cite>. Furthermore, the institution's ability to generate <cite id="16">$835,237 in program service revenue</cite> suggests a sustainable model that balances charitable contributions with tuition-based income.
rich_narrative.summary: Darul Qasim is an Illinois-based Islamic institution dedicated to the preservation and dissemination of traditional religious knowledge through <cite id="1">rigorous academic programs in Arabic and Islamic studies</cite>. The organization operates with a mission to facilitate learning derived from the <cite id="2">prophethood of Muhammad and religious education</cite>, primarily serving the Muslim community in the United States. In the 2023 tax year, the institution reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $3,290,091</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="4">three-year revenue growth rate of 23.4%</cite>. Its educational framework is structured around specialized tracks, including the <cite id="5">Shaykh al-Hind Program and Takhaṣṣuṣ specialization programs</cite>, which aim to build intellectual capacity within the American Muslim landscape. While the organization maintains <cite id="6">strong liquidity with 29.3 months of working capital</cite>, its financial model shows a <cite id="7">program expense ratio of 51.9%</cite>, which is lower than the <cite id="8">peer median of 78.4%</cite> for global education non-profits. Despite this, the charity demonstrates <cite id="9">exceptional fundraising efficiency</cite>, spending only <cite id="10">$0.02 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions. Darul Qasim is <cite id="11">zakat-eligible</cite>, specifically utilizing these funds to support students through its <cite id="12">zakat distribution policy</cite>.
